items.title: Ever curious about the front-end?
items.summary: The front-end is more than just making things pretty
items.text:
The front-end is usually about making things pretty. Is that the case though? Most of the time, yes. But when you are dealing with game dev or software dev that has interactive features, the front-end is no longer making the UI good, but also the UX. For example, in StudiLib, the front-end is consisted of the character, the background, and most importantly, how each scene transitions and how smoothing the animation is...since nobody loves a laggy software. 

In a standard web app, if a button doesn't respond in 100ms, the user thinks the internet is slow. In an interactive scene like StudiLib, if the character doesn't respond in 16ms (the window for 60fps), the user thinks the software is trash. 

Therefore, the devs are working hard to make sure the sfotware runs very smoothly. ;)

items.title: Building a Home for our Thoughts
items.summary: StudiLib gets a major facelift: introducing the new Updates log and the official Dev Blog.
items.text:
The code is finally coming together. 

Up until now, StudiLib was mostly a collection of local scripts and big dreams. But as any developer knows, if you don't document the journey, the journey eventually consumes you. That’s why I’ve spent the last few days building out the infrastructure for our two newest sections: Updates and Blogs.

### The Updates Section
Transparency is key. I wanted a way for you to see exactly what we’re working on in real-time. Whether it's a backend fix for the Pomodoro sync or a new pixel asset added to the Study Town, you'll find it in the 'Progress Log.' It’s more than just a changelog; it’s a heartbeat for the project.

### Why a Blog?
Because coding isn't hard—but explaining the 'why' behind the code can be. I hate writing and drawing as much as the next dev, but StudiLib is a community project at its core. This blog is where we’ll share the 'Science of Study,' deep dives into our development stages, and maybe a few rants about CSS positioning along the way.

We’ve refined the UI to keep that cozy, monospace-meets-pixel aesthetic. The blog pages now feature a cleaner, editorial layout that prioritizes readability, complete with a 'Read Time' estimator (for those of us who need to get back to our Pomodoro sessions quickly).

Check out the Documentation for the technical 'how-to,' or stick around here for the 'behind-the-scenes' stories. Either way, we’re glad you’re part of the library.
